textline.text: Gordon C. C. Douglas, Ph.D.
The Institute for Public Knowledge, New York University
gdouglas@nyu.edu ● 323 286 3736
Current Position
Postdoctoral Fellow and Associate Director, The Institute for Public Knowledge, New York University.
Education and Awards
PhD, Sociology, University of Chicago, 2014
Dissertation: Do-It-Yourself Urban Design: Inequality, Privilege, and Creative Transgression in the Help-
Yourself City.
Committee: Mario L. Small (chair), Andrew Abbott, and Kristen Schilt.
Recipient of the 2013-14 Henderson Dissertation Fellowship, a 2010 Doolittle-Harrison Travel Grant, a
2009 Provost's Summer Research Fellowship, and the 2009 Society for Social Research Writing Prize.
MA, Sociology, University of Chicago, 2008
Thesis: The Impact of Social Norms on Growth Machine Development: Local Culture and the
Development Process in an Identity-Conscious Community.
MSc, Global Media, London School of Economics and Political Science, 2005
MA, Global Communication, USC Annenberg School for Communication, 2005
Thesis: The Art of Spatial Resistance: The Global Urban Network of Street Art.
Recipient of the 2004-05 Annenberg Lenny Sands Fellowship.
BA, magna cum laude, International Relations, University of Southern California, 2003
Recipient of the 2003 Michael Sullivan Award.
Books & Edited Volumes
2012 C. L. Ho & G. Douglas (eds.) Spontaneous Interventions: Design Actions for the Common Good,
catalogue for the exhibition of the same name, United States Pavilion, 13th Venice
International Biennale of Architecture. Washington, DC: Architect Magazine/Hanley Wood.
August, 2012.
In preparation
Douglas, G. C. C. The Help-Yourself City: What DIY Urbanism Tells Us about Inequality,
Citizenship, and New Cultures of Placemaking (revise & resubmit with Univ. of Chicago Press).
Peer-Reviewed Journal Articles & Book Chapters
forth. Douglas, G. C. C. "The Formalities of Informal Improvement: Technical and Scholarly Knowledge
at Work in DIY Urban Design," The Journal of Urbanism: Research on Placemaking and Urban
Sustainability (in press; published online 9 April 2015).
2014 Douglas, G. C. C. "Do-it-Yourself Urban Design: The Social Practice of Informal 'Improvement'
Through Unauthorized Alteration," City and Community, vol. 13, no. 1. 5-25.
2012 Douglas, G. C. C. "The Edge of the Island: Cultural Ideology and Neighborhood Identity at the
Gentrification Frontier," Urban Studies, vol. 49, no. 16. 3579-3594.
2012 Douglas, G. C. C. "Cultural Expectations and Urban Development: The Role of 'Cultural
Sensitivity' and 'Cultural Sincerity' in Local Growth Politics," Sociological Perspectives, vol. 55,
2010 Douglas, G. C. C. "Rail Transit Identification and Neighbourhood Identity: Exploring the Potential
for 'Community-Supportive Transit,'" The Journal of Urban Design, vol. 15, no. 2. 175-193.
In preparation
Douglas, G. C. C. "Do-it-Yourself City," in Orum, Anthony M., ed., The Wiley-Blackwell
Encyclopedia of Urban and Regional Studies. Chichester, UK & Malden, MA: John Wiley & Sons
(invited).
Douglas, G. C. C. "'We Should be Able to Do it Ourselves': The Politics of DIY Bicycle
Infrastructure," in S. McCullough & A. Lugo, eds., Bicicultures (chapter proposal accepted for
inclusion).
Douglas, G. C. C. "Translocal Cultures of Creative Transgression: Inspiration, Reproduction, and
Innovation in Multi-City Street Art and DIY Urbanism" (working paper).
Douglas, G. C. C., L. Koslov, & E. Klinenberg. "Organizational Cultures and Complex
Infrastructures in New York’s Experience of Hurricane Sandy" (working paper).
L. Koslov, Douglas, G. C. C. & E. Klinenberg. "Cities, Class, and Climate Change: Evidence from
Superstorm Sandy" (working paper).
Douglas, G. C. C. "The Sociology of Urban Planning – A Critical Review of a Century-Long
Transdisciplinary Dialogue" (working paper).
Other Publications
forth. Douglas, G. Review of Tactical Urbanism, by Mike Lydon and Anthony Garcia, Journal of the
American Planning Association (in press; published online 30 June, 2015).
2015 Douglas, G. Review of Cities by Design, by Fran Tonkiss, American Journal of Sociology, vol. 120,

2015 Douglas, G. Review of three books on informal placemaking, Architectural Record, vol. 203, no. 6

GOOD, 29 Aug. 2012. http://www.good.is/post/open-source-urbanism-venice-biennale-puts-

eds. Spontaneous Interventions: Design Actions for the Common Good, catalogue for the
exhibition of the same name, United States Pavilion, 13th Venice International Biennale of

Disobedience," Architect / Ho & Douglas, eds. Spontaneous Interventions, catalogue for the
exhibition of the same name, United States Pavilion, 13th Venice International Biennale of

2011. http://www.good.is/post/diy-urban-design-from-guerrilla-gardening-to-yarn-bombing/.
2010 Douglas, G. "The Back Garden Project" (series), GOOD, April - Aug. 2010.
http://www.good.is/series/back-garden-project/.
2009 Douglas, G. "What is Glamour? The Production and Consumption of a Working Aesthetic,"
MU-DOT: the Magazine for Urban Documentation, Opinion and Theory, no. 2, Aug. 2009. 44-63.
Conference Presentations
forth. "Conveniently Located Disaster: Socio-Spatial Inequality in Hurricane Sandy and Its Implications
for the Urban Sociology of Climate Change, " paper presented at the American Sociological
Association Annual Conference, Chicago (with Eric Klinenberg & Liz Koslov).
"Trans-Local Cultural Geographies of Creative Transgression: Inspiration, Reproduction, and
Innovation in Multi-City Street Art and DIY Urbanism," paper presented at the Association of
American Geographers Annual Conference, Chicago (invited).
"Help-Yourself City: Market-Driven Planning and DIY Responses in Making the Neoliberal
Streetscape," paper presented at the American Sociological Association Annual Conference, San
Francisco.
"The Formalities of Informal Urbanism: Technical and Scholarly Knowledge at Work in Do-it-
Yourself Urban Design," paper presented at the American Sociological Association Annual
Conference, New York.
"The Self-Conscious Gentrifier: The Paradox of Authenticity and Impact Among 'First-Wave' Neo-
Bohemians in Two Changing Neighborhoods," paper presented at the American Sociological
Association Annual Conference, Denver (with Naomi Bartz).
"Lefebvre and Whyte Hit the Streets: The Diffusion of Scholarly Urbanism and the Rise of the
Informal Urban Designer," paper presented at the Chicago Ethnography Conference, Chicago.
"Don't Wait for Anybody to Give You Permission: Unauthorized Urban Design 'Contributions' in
the Contemporary City," paper presented at the Association of American Geographers Annual
Conference, New York.
"Parsing the Evolving Politics and Practice of D.I.Y.," invited panel organized at the Association of
American Geographers Annual Conference, New York (with Brian J. Hracs).
"Do-It-Yourself Urban Design: Making Local Improvements through Unauthorized Alterations of
Urban Space," paper presented at the American Sociological Association Annual Conference, Las
Vegas.
Specific Art and Activism," paper presented at the Association of American Geographers Annual
Conference, Seattle.
2011 "Do-It-Yourself Urban Design: Reimagining the Built Environment through Place-Based, Site-
"Architecture for Everyone? The Synthesis of Design Interface and Individual Expression in the
Age of Malleable Architecture," paper accepted for presentation at the International Conference
on Design Principles and Practices, Rome (with Joshua Van Blankenship).
"Expression, Critique, and Resistance in Localized Practices of Contesting and Reclaiming Urban
Space," paper presented at the Royal Geographical Society Annual Conference, London.
"The Edge of the Island: Neighborhood Identity and Evolving Community in 'Liminal Places,'"
paper presented at the American Sociological Association Annual Conference, Atlanta.
"Cultural Sincerity in Urban Development," paper presented at the American Sociological
Association Annual Conference, San Francisco.
Teaching Experience
'Photographing Chicago Landscapes,' Fall 2008 and Fall 2009 (instructor of record)
Adjunct Lecturer, DePaul University Dept. of Sociology
Employing photography as a way of reading urban place and culture, my course used in-class
discussion, regular excursions, and student field research to introduce the city and its neighborhoods to
undergraduate students while providing an introduction to the urban sociology literature. Topics
included culture and identity, community history, inequality and demographic change, the use and
meaning of the built landscape, and local politics and development issues.
'Field Research Practicum in Public Policy,' Winter and Spring 2009
Teaching Assistant for Dr. Chad Broughton, University of Chicago Public Policy Studies Program
Sole instructor for methods sections on demographic and spatial data analysis, presentation skills, and
graphic design. The two-quarter undergraduate course organized students to think of themselves as a
provisional think tank or consulting group, learning a variety of research, writing, and presentation skills
through studying a real local issue and crafting a report with actionable recommendations
commissioned by the City of Chicago’s Department of Family and Support Services.
'Urban Structure and Process,' Spring 2008 and Spring 2009
T.A. for Dr. Omar McRoberts, University of Chicago Dept. of Sociology
Gave full lectures and assisted in writing exams, in addition to traditional T.A. duties. Course reviewed
competing theories of urban development and consideration of emerging metropolitan regions, the
microstructure of local neighborhoods, and the limitations of past American experience as a way of
developing urban policy in the U.S. and elsewhere.
'Urban Policy Analysis,' Fall 2007
T.A. for Dr. Terry Nichols Clark, University of Chicago Dept. of Sociology
Provided tutorials on policy analysis techniques and assisted in course re-design and exam writing, in
additional to other duties. Course addressed explanations for varying policy patterns that cities provide
through examination of migration, group theory, citizen preference theory, incrementalism, economic
base influences, and an integrated model.
'Health and Human Rights,' Spring 2007
T.A. for Dr. John Schumann, University of Chicago Human Rights Program
Led weekly discussion sections for 30 students, in addition to typical T.A. duties. Course examined
health and health care in context of human rights theory and practice. Topics included health care
system of the U.S. in comparison with other nations, issues of health and medical practice in urban areas
and areas of conflict, and the study of vulnerable populations and social determinants of health.
'Intervention and Public Practice,' Spring 2007
Student Teaching Assistant for instructor Theaster Gates, University of Chicago Dept. of Visual Arts
Invited to serve as teaching assistant for course on history, criticism, and practice of public and
interventionist art. Helped to lead reading discussions and to orchestrate large-scale art intervention
happening on the South Side of Chicago and university campus.

Guest Instructor, "Research Methods (Urban Core Lab)," Prof. Aurash Khawarzad, Parsons the New
School for Design, 2014
Guest Instructor (with James Rojas), Arch. Studio, Pratt Institute School of Architecture, 2012
Guest Instructor, "Qualitative Research Methods," Prof. Daniel Huebner, American University, 2013
Guest Instructor, "The Sociology of Deviant Behavior," Prof. Kristen Schilt, University of Chicago, 2011
Invited talk, "Methodological Considerations for a Sociology of Urban Planning," University of Chicago
Urban Network, 2015
Invited talk, "From Park(ing) Day to Parklet Dining: Creative Placemaking and the Spatial Reproduction of
Inequality," NYU Furman Center for Real-Estate and Urban Policy, 2015
Moderator, "Oculus Book Talk: Tactical Urbanism," American Institute of Architects New York Center for
Architecture, 2015
Moderator, "Placemaking in the Creative Capital," Brown-RISD Innovating Urban Districts colloquium,
Brown University, 2015
Moderator, "Scholarly Perspectives on Spontaneous Interventions," Chicago Cultural Center, 2013
Moderator, "The Social Life of Urban Spaces," U.S. Pavilion, Venice Architecture Biennale, 2012
Moderator, "Productive Landscapes," U.S. Pavilion, Venice Architecture Biennale, 2012
Panelist, "Good Neighbors: Gentrifying Diversity in Boston’s South End" book talk, NYU, 2015
Panelist, "Syracuse University Gentrification Lab NYC: Politics of Place," Van Alen Institute, 2015
Panelist, "The Open City: Rapid Prototyping Strategies that Enable Citizen-Led Improvements to Places,
Neighbor Interactions, and Civic Processes," World Maker Faire New York, 2014
Panelist, "Spontaneous Urbanisms," Chicago Cultural Center, 2013
Panelist, Chicago Urban Network / Doc Films screening of Urbanized, University of Chicago, 2012
Panelist, Spontaneous Interventions Discussion, NYC International Contemporary Furniture Fair, 2012

Project Manager and Curatorial Advisor, Spontaneous Interventions: Design Actions for the Common
Good, The Institute for Urban Design / U.S. Department of State (New York), Nov. 2011 – Oct. 2013
Visiting Researcher / Volunteer, Isla Urbana (Mexico City), Feb. 2012 – Aug. 2012
Translation Editor for Transatlantische Bereicherungen, Dr. Christian Fleck, University of Graz /
Suhrkamp Verlag (Berlin), May – July 2010
Consultant, "Urban Art Changes Neighborhoods" Public Service Initiative, Sundance Channel (New York),
Research Assistant, Historical Spatial Analysis of U.S. Fall Line Zone, Dr. Hoyt Bleakley, University of
Chicago Graduate School of Business, Mar. 2008 – Oct. 2008
Spatial Data Analyst, Obama for America Presidential Campaign (Chicago), Mar. 2008 – July 2008
Mapping Assistant, "Subjective Constructions of Neighborhood Boundaries," Dr. Julia Henly, University
of Chicago School of Social Service Administration, Winter 2008
Special Projects Officer, Relief International – Schools Online (Los Angeles & New York), Sept. 2005 –
Sands Research Fellow, Center on Public Diplomacy, University of Southern California Annenberg School,
Aug. 2004 – July 2005

Member, Association of American Geographers, since 2010

Reviewer, Public Culture, since 2014
Reviewer, Journal of Geography in Higher Education, 2014
Reviewer, Planning Practice and Research, 2014
Reviewer, City and Community, since 2013
Reviewer, Journal of Urbanism, since 2012
Reviewer, Journal of Urban Design, 2010
Reviewer, American Journal of Sociology, since 2009
Participant, NYLON workshop, New York University, 2012 – present
Participant, NYLON conference, Max Planck Institute for Human Development (Berlin), 2014
Participant, Gil Lopez Ace AIR residency – Creatives as Social Capital, Ace Hotel New York, 2014
Participant, NYLON conference, New York University, 2014
Participant, Governance and Politics in the Changing American City conference, Harvard University, 2013
Participant, Exploring the Creative Economy conference, University of Toronto, 2011
Participant, Politics and Protest workshop, CUNY Graduate Center (New York), 2010-2011
Participant, Social Theory and Evidence workshop, University of Chicago, 2008-2011
Participant, City Society and Space workshop, University of Chicago, 2007-2011
Technical Skills and Qualifications
Skilled in ESRI ArcGIS (ArcInfo, Map, Catalog) spatial analytics, Adobe Photoshop Pro, SPSS, HTML,
Microsoft Office (Excel, Word, etc.). Experience with U.S. Census Bureau TIGER files and other
government data, spatial and otherwise. Published photographer. Speak, read, and write Spanish and
German with fair proficiency. (Also studied French, Arabic, and Chinese at rudimentary levels.)
